Reif and Bugos (2020). May 27, stated that:

In his first public comments this month, Special Envoy for Arms Control Marshall Billingslea described his initial engagement with his Russian counterpart, criticized the 2010 New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START), and sketched out some of the administration’s goals for a new trilateral agreement (Para. 33). In remarks at a May 21 event at the Hudson Institute, Billingslea said that he and Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergey Ryabkov agreed in a May 8 phone call “to meet, talk about our respective concerns and objectives, and find a way forward to begin negotiations” on a new arms control agreement. “So, we have settled on a venue, and we are working on an agenda based on the exchange of views that has taken place,” he added. The location of the dialogue is most likely to be Vienna. On New START, which expires in February 2021 unless President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin agree to extend it by up to five years, Billingslea said that “potential extension of our existing obligations must be tied to progress towards a new era of arms control.” Russia has stated that it is ready to extend New START without any preconditions, but the Trump administration remains undecided on the treaty’s fate (Para. 33-37).

US Russia New START talks starting says envoy

WASHINGTON ― Early U.S.-Russia talks to renew the New START arms control treaty have begun, and the two sides have agreed to an in-person dialogue due once the coronavirus pandemic subsides, according to a top State Department official. Arms control envoy Marshall Billingslea announced Thursday he is in nascent talks with his Russian counterpart, Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov. The news comes a month after Moscow has signaled readiness to include some of its latest nuclear weapons in the last remaining arms control pact between the two countries, if the U.S. agrees to extend the treaty.

Marshall Billingslea, a veteran national official appointed to the State Department post last month, said in an exclusive interview that before Moscow begins to think about any kind of extension of the 10-year-old nuclear arms limitation treaty, Russia must “bring the Chinese to the negotiating table” as well. Overall, however, Mr. Billingslea said the United States is not interested in “arms control for arms control’s sake,” a criticism leveled at many policymakers and advocates of treaties and negotiations. New START contains “many glaring deficiencies,” and President Trump is not interested in perpetuating the flawed treaty approved by his predecessor.
. . .
Chinese government officials have repeatedly said Beijing has no interest in joining three-way talks on an expanded New START deal because their arsenal is far smaller than those of the U.S. and Russia.
“China opposes any country talking out of turn about China on the issue of arms control, and will not take part in any trilateral negotiations on a nuclear disarmament agreement,” Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang told a news briefing in Beijing this week.
Chinese officials also believe talks will require disclosing information about nuclear forces that will undermine its deterrence. The number of Chinese warheads is not known because of Chinese military secrecy, but is estimated to be at least 250 strategic warheads and an undisclosed number of smaller warheads.
The government of Russian President Vladimir Putin has proposed extending the New START between the U.S. and Russia for another five years, a move that could be made without congressional approval under the treaty. Mr. Putin and Mr. Trump discussed the standoff over New START in a direct phone call Thursday that also dealt with the coronavirus crisis.
During the call, Mr. Trump “reaffirmed that the United States is committed to effective arms control that includes not only Russia, but also China, and looks forward to future discussions to avoid a costly arms race,” the White House said in a statement.
Russian officials say an unconditional five-year extension would give both sides more time to discuss a multilateral deal involving China, but longtime Putin aide Dmitry Medvedev recently wrote for the Tass news agency that “the United States does not seek, contrary to what was seen 10 years ago, to engage in a serious, honest and professional dialogue.”
Asked about Beijing’s refusal to join the talks, Mr. Billingslea said that if China wants to be a great power as its leaders keep saying, they should behave like one and join the arms talks.
. . . 
Mr. Billingslea comes to the arms control post with lengthy experience in government, most recently as a point person at the Treasury Department for international relations, sanctions and other punitive measures that have been key features of the Trump administration’s policies toward adversaries and rogue states.
A new U.S. arms strategy is nearing completion and, once finished, “I will be willing be to engage the Russians to listen to their views and understand why they are so desperate for the extension of the New START treaty,” he said.
Asked if Mr. Trump has decided whether to extend the treaty, Mr. Billingslea said, “We want to understand why the Russians are so desperate for extension, and we want the Russians to explain to us why this is in our interest to do it.”
. . . 
Mr. Billingslea said a new arms agreement with the United States, China and Russia must be binding and contain verifiable and enforceable provisions.
. . . 
Russia’s economic difficulties put the United States in a strong negotiating position, he said.
. . . 
Mr. Billingslea has not held talks yet with the Russians but noted that Moscow is keen to begin New START extension negotiations.
China’s nuclear buildup will be a topic of discussion with Moscow officials, and Mr. Billingslea reiterated that it is in Russia’s interest to persuade Beijing to join arms talks.
. . . 
For arms control advocates who say Russia will accelerate its buildup without a New START extension, Mr. Billingslea said, “I’m not sure they aren’t doing that already, at least with their unconstrained nuclear stockpile.”
He also noted that Moscow has limited resources for a faster nuclear buildup and will be unable to accelerate its programs.
“In my case, you’re talking to someone who has for the past three years very systematically examined the workings of adversarial economies and understands how to use financial tools to support U.S. national security,” Mr. Billingslea said.

Based on my analysis, I assess there is a 1% probability of negotiations beginning before 1 October 2020 regarding the New START treaty. This is due to the following reasons: The social/economic issues resulting from the COVID-19 outbreak, the upcoming general election, opposition to negotiations inside the Trump administration, and the desire of the US to make START a multi-lateral treaty. First and foremost, the Trump administration will be heavily focused on domestic issues for the next 2-4 months as the country faces the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. In the near-term, the administration will be focused on addressing US GDP concerns, which could drop 40% in the second quarter of 2020 [1]. It will also be focused on the record number of unemployed Americans which could reach a total of 20% of the workforce [2]. These issues will force the Administration to focus their attention on how to repair small businesses, gig workers and consumer spending. The second major reason that the Trump administration is unlikely to negotiate the New START treaty before 1 October is because Joseph R. Biden is now the presumptive Democratic nominee. This is important because the New START treaty was negotiated by the Obama administration. If President Donald J. Trump enters into negotiations, or extends it, he could be seen as approving of the job President Obama did on that negotiation. This would go against his long-standing stance that almost everything accomplished by the Obama administration was bad, in fact, President Donald J. Trump denounced the New START as a “bad Obama administration agreement” [3]. It would also put President Donald J. Trump in a position of weakness vis-à-vis Joseph R. Biden as he was the Vice President during the Obama administration. Any agreement with Russia could also prove to have significant blow-back with the American public, due to his previous interactions with Russia, if the United States comes across as weak at the negotiating table. Thirdly, individuals in (or formerly in) the Trump administration are against extending/negotiating New START for a variety of reasons including new Russian weapon systems and a desire to create a brand new treaty that would increase U.S. leverage across all nuclear weapons, including non-nuclear weapons [4]. In fact, President Donald J. Trump has mentioned replacing New START with a treaty that encompasses all types of nuclear weapons, not just the ones currently included in New START. Finally, the Trump administration has mentioned multiple times, over multiple months, that it wants to include China in the treaty [6]. However, China has stated multiple times that it has no interest in joining negotiations because its nuclear weapon stockpile is significantly smaller than those of the US and Russia [7]. The administration could be using this as a pretense to back away from any negotiations as some in the Trump administration allegedly believe that, “Cold War-era arms controls are holding the U.S. back from their ‘dream of a world of American Nuclear Superiority.’”[8]. This ties in with the Trump administrations apparent beliefs that bi-lateral treaties are antiquated and the US faces a direct military threat from China [9] President Donald J. Trump has also instructed the Department of State to think bigger than just Russia on New START, but DoS is running into difficulties in that regard due to being understaffed and the Administration not having a prioritized list of foreign policy objectives [10]. Ultimately, the Trump administration has had major issues nailing down substantive foreign policy victories. It also has not been receptive to Russian requests to renew the New START treaty [11] and seems to want a wide-ranging tri-lateral agreement that ushers in sweeping reforms. It would also could cause President Donald J. Trump some unneeded political needling from Joseph R. Biden if he embraced the New START treaty due to the Obama administrations involvement in creating that agreement. Finally, the economic impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic will be wide-ranging and, most likely, will take up much of the Trump administrations time and energy as this issue is more important, both politically and to the American people, than the New START treaty. Overall, it seems unlikely that the treaty would be extended.  While proponents claim that it has strengthened international security and strategic stability, and Russia has indicated its willingness in the past to discuss extensions, President Trump is no stranger to flouting established international norms and is a vocal critic of nearly all of Obama’s policies.  He has expressed the desire to renegotiate a better deal for the US with respect to US-Russian arms agreements, and has also indicated that he wants to involve China in the next treaty iteration: this would serve no purpose for China as it has a far smaller nuclear arsenal than either of the other two countries and thus would clearly get the short end of the stick in any deal involving the three.  Lastly, the coronavirus pandemic means that, for the moment, the treaty is not the highest priority for the Trump administration; this may change if the pandemic comes under control, but for the moment Trump’s attention is surely divided.
